Above Treeline
No Rating (-) Watch for signs of instability like recent avalanches, cracking, and audible collapsing. Avoid traveling on or under similar slopes.   No Rating (-) Watch for signs of instability like recent avalanches, cracking, and audible collapsing. Avoid traveling on or under similar slopes.
Near Treeline
Considerable (3) Dangerous avalanche conditions. Cautious route-finding and conservative decision-making essential.   Moderate (2) Heightened avalanche conditions on specific terrain features. Evaluate snow and terrain carefully.

Summary

Although the chances are slowly decreasing, you can still trigger large dangerous avalanches that break deep in the snowpack. You are most likely to trigger these avalanches from thin spots around rocks, or near the edges of slabs where the weak layers are closer to the surface making them easier to trigger. To stay safe in the mountains this weekend, avoidance is the key. It is getting harder for riders to trigger avalanches; however, if you do trigger an avalanche it will most likely be large and inescapable. To avoid avalanches, stick to lower angle slopes with no avalanche terrain above you. If you do chose to move into steeper terrain, you need to know that avalanches are not behaving in a very predictable way right now. You will not see signs of instability such as cracking or collapsing to help you make decisions.   

Whether you use the CAIC forecast every day or once a year, please consider becoming a Friend of CAIC by making a donation today. https://avalanche.state.co.us/donate/"

What You Need to Know About These Avalanches


Persistent Slab avalanches can be triggered days to weeks after the last storm. They often propagate across and beyond terrain features that would otherwise confine Wind and Storm Slab avalanches. In some cases they can be triggered remotely, from low-angle terrain or adjacent slopes. Give yourself a wide safety buffer to address the uncertainty.

What You Need to Know About These Avalanches


Wind Slab avalanches release naturally during wind events and can be triggered for up to a week after a wind event. They form in lee and cross-loaded terrain features. Avoid them by sticking to wind sheltered or wind scoured areas.

Sat, Mar 16, 2019 at 8:10 AM
Issued by: Ben Pritchett Statewide Weather Forecast  

An historically deep snowpack now blankets the Central Mountains. Many areas are near or over 150% of average for this time of year, with the most significant portion of the snowpack developing in the last month. Since the beginning of March, the snowfall and avalanches have been record-breaking.

Personally, I'm going to tune up my chainsaw this spring. I'll need it in good shape this summer to access the backcountry roads now covered in with piles of avalanche debris filled with trees. Avalanches have trimmed forests bounding and re-growing within avalanche paths region wide. These avalanches are getting harder to trigger as the deep snowpack stiffens over the top of now deeply buried weak layers.

While natural avalanches are diminishing in frequency, though not size, they can still happen. Large hanging cornices are one of the greatest concerns right now. If one breaks and falls on a slope, it could provide the large jolt needed to set off yet another tree-breaking, valley-burying avalanche. Pay attention to what's above you, and avoid slopes that haven't avalanche recently especially those topped with a large cornice.

The second significant concern are slopes with a shallower snowpack depth. These are most common in the Sawatch Range, but also present in the eastern and southern Gunnison zone and northern Aspen zone. If you find a slab that's one to three feet thick resting on a weak faceted base, these are the easiest slopes to trigger. Many low elevation areas that typically would hold very little snow fit this description.

The bottom line is that safe travel requires planning and on-site observation. Know when you will be exposed to large slopes overhead. Pay attention to what has and has not yet avalanched. Those that haven't slid might. Track the snow cover, and avoid shallow areas within and below avalanche paths like the plague.
  • Deployed air bag of snowmobiler that was partially buried by an avalanche below treeline on an east facing slope near Horse Mtn (full)
  • Avalanche near Horse Mtn that caught and partially buried a snowmobiler (full)
  • Triggered slide in West Riverside from 3.9.19. Snow shed is under there somewhere (full)
